direction.raw_text: establishing the race track, Ruidoso Downs (pronounced Ree-oh-do-so), set among the beautiful mountains of New Mexico's Lincoln National Forest, as a white Chrysler turns in with a stream of cars moving toward the parking area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: through the open driver-side window of the Chrysler at LILLY DILLON, 39 but looking younger, beautiful but cold and watchful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , track in b.g. as Lilly parks the Chrysler, gets out, locks the car. As she walks toward the track, WIPE RIGHT, as SCENE TWO WIPES IN from the left. SCENE ONE CAMERA FOLLOWS Lilly as she walks across the large parking area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Downtown Los Angeles, near the courts and the business section. ROY DILLON, 25, handsome and charming but self indulgent, parks his orange Honda convertible, gets out, picks up a large ledger book from the back seat, goes around to open the trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the trunk, establishing the tools of the salesman's trade: catalogs, samples, ledgers full of manuals and product sheets. Roy adds the ledger from the back seat, shuts the trunk, walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy walks around the corner near a bar/restaurant. As he approaches it, WIPE LEFT, the two half-width scenes contracting to one-third each as SCENE THREE WIPES IN from the right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Lilly approaches the track's entrance doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Roy approaches the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A baby blue Cadillac parks in front of a jeweler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the driver's door as MYRA LANGTRY, 36, beautiful in an impersonal calculating way, gets out, carrying a small jewelry care, and locks the car. At first glance, Myra looks rather like Lilly. (Myra always wears large dangly earrings, and usually wears big-lensed dark sunglasses.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Lilly enters the track.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Roy enters the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Myra enters the jeweler's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as SCENE TWO takes FULL SCREEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a hurried bartender in a full bar, crowded with a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lunchtime crowd. In b.g., Roy slithers his way to the bar, waving a bill in the air to attract the bartender's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy as the bartender comes to him. Roy puts the bill on the bar, holding it down with one finger, as he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: his order. The bartender looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Roy's finger holds down a twenty dollar bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: steep over Roy's shoulder, the twenty visible, as the bartender hurries away to get the drink. Roy's hand makes a fist, swallowing the twenty, opens, pushing a ten out onto the bar, holding it there with one finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the bartender returning with a draft beer, nodding to other ORDERS shouted to him along the way, putting the beer down, grabbing the bill without looking at it, hurrying away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy, content, smiling, sipping his beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the bartender, hurrying by, slapping Roy's change down, moving on, Roy nodding acknowledgement, reaching out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the change, a ten dollar bill on top. Roy's hand closes over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , the tote board at the track, showing the shifting odds on the horses for the next race, the amounts bet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , number 3. Not much bet, odds 70-1.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly, frowning at the tote board. She carries a large heavy shoulder-bag, which she opens, looking in it as though it were a file drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly studying the contents of her bag, the track beyond her, the mountains visible out beyond the track wall. Lilly moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a high-dollar betting window, as Lilly approaches, taking bank-banded wads of bills from her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A change of numbers sweeps across the board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly moves away from the betting window, tucking betting tickets into her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly's bag, compartmented, with stacks of money, small envelopes and notes on notepaper in each compartment. Lilly carefully files the betting slips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly looking out at the tote board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: number 3. Odds 32-1.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly, not satisfied. She turns and goes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at the betting window as Lilly arrives and makes more bets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: number 3. Odds 32-1. CROWD NOISE INCREASES. The numbers shift: odds 26-1.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they're off!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very quiet, stately; abrupt contrast with the track. A slow ticking clock. Myra sits in the client's chair, while at the desk sits the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a pleasant but overweight man of 40, who studies a jeweled bracelet through a loupe. He sighs, drops the loupe, shakes his head regretfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Langtry, I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a valued customer, as you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't understand a thing like this. It's something you almost never see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is some of the finest filigreed platinum I've ever seen. But the stones, no. They're not diamonds, Mrs. Langtry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they must be! They cut glass!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass will cut glass, Mrs. Langtry. Do you know where it was purchased?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An expensive hotel room, with a sunstruck day beyond the windows. Myra, naked, a few years younger, sits cross-legged on the bed and laughs at COLE "FARMER" LANGLEY, 55, stringy bodied, who stands naked, his back to us, hands on hips, presenting himself to Myra. She reaches forward, hand hidden by his body as she lifts something that was hanging on something at the front of him. She brings back the bracelet, looks at it, is delighted, puts it on, and then leans forward again toward the unmoving Cole, her head hidden by his body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was a gift. It isn't worth anything at all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, of course it is. I can offer you -- well, five hundred dollars. Myra expected -- and needed -- a lot more. She's worried, tense, but stuck. She nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get you a check. He leaves the room. Myra grimaces, in almost physical pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another crowded lunchtime bar. A big beefy BARTENDER moves quickly, carrying a draft beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy, in position, finger holding bill down, as the bartender arrives, puts down the beer, reaches for the bill, stops, stares at the bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , the bartender and Roy, as the bartender gives Roy a very cold look. He knows, and Roy knows he knows. Roy tries an innocent smile, which doesn't work. Roy moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the ten dollar bill, as Roy grabs it, but the bartender simultaneously grabs Roy's wrist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy and the bartender as Roy tries to pull away and the bartender holds him with his left hand while reaching under the bar with his right. He comes up with a sawed-off baseball bat. Roy, seeing it, throws his free arm up to protect his head, but the bartender pushes the blunt end of the bat straight across the bar at a downward angle and hard into Roy's solar plexus, driving the air out of him and propelling him back away from the bar, leaving the ten. The nearest CUSTOMERS on both sides become aware that something happened, but nothing follows and they're already involved in conversations. The bartender scoops up the ten as he puts the bat away under the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy, arms folded across his torso, staring in shock toward the bar, where the space he filled has already been closed in by other bodies. Nearly retching, he stumbles toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on four PEOPLE at a table, CHEERING a race, switching to disgust and despair when they lose, moving away from the table, leaving their betting tickets behind. Lilly passes by, smoothly and casually scoops up the tickets, moves on along a row of tables, and there finding more tickets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra sits as before. The jeweler enters with a check, which he hands her. She looks up at him, making no move to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you're not too badly disappointed with us, Mrs. Langtry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not your fault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll give us an opportunity to serve you again, I hope. If there's anything you think we might be interested in...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have only one thing now. Are you interested?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'd have to see it, of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are seeing it. You're looking right at it. The jeweler is puzzled, then startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. He turns away, goes behind his desk, sits down, looks at Myra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know something, Mrs. Langtry? A bracelet like that very rarely happens. A fine setting and workmanship usually mean precious stones. It always hurts me when I find they're not. I always hope -- (faint sad friendly smile)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm mistaken. Myra likes him better now, even though he hasn't solved her problem. She rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. For everything you felt you could do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy has been throwing up but is finished now. He's sprawled like a shot deer across the hood of his Honda, still clutching his stomach. A police car stops, the passenger COP gets out. He's suspicious at first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir? Everything all right? The sight of the uniform forces Roy into gear. He straightens, smiling through his pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting better. A bad shrimp, I think. The con's suspicion changes to concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want us to take you to a doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No no, I'm fine now, thanks, anyway. Still got a lot of clients to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy, now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Late afternoon. AN ANGLE on the parking area, where almost all the cars are gone and the few remaining are widely separated. The white Chrysler is one of these. Lilly walks to it from the track entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the Chrysler as Lilly opens the trunk, puts her bag inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP, Lilly and the trunk. She takes betting tickets from her bag, sorts them, files them in envelopes in different compartments, puts some to one side, then sorts through these separated tickets, throwing some away, keeping some. She takes money from the bag, puts tickets in, closes the bag with the money on the trunk floor. Reaching farther in, she lifts the pad deep inside the trunk, lifts the metal floor panel, and reveals a cache mostly filled with money. She adds today's skim, puts everything away, puts the bag back on her shoulder, closes the trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shabby apartment hotel on Wilshire. An exterior hall balcony on each floor has the entrance doors to the front apartments. Roy's Honda makes the turn and enters the basement garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Modest but clean. The owner, SIMMS, a sloppy garrulous old bore, talks with a potential RENTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put it this way, now. Say I rent to a woman, well, she has to have a room with a bath. I insist on it, because otherwise she's got the hall bath tied up all the time, washing her goddamn hair and her clothes and everything she can think of. In b.g., Roy, still in pain, comes out of the elevator, waves to Simms, who waves back without pausing in his monologue, and crosses to the mailboxes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, your minimum for a room with bath is three hundred a month, just for a place to sleep and no cooking allowed. And just how many of these tootsies make that kind of money and have to eat in restaurants and buy clothes and -- Roy, carrying his junk mail and pretending not to be in pain, crosses to Simms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Simms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why yes, Mr. Dillon. Here's a potential new neighbor, looking at--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh. Mrs. Langtry may drop by. Simms doesn't like Mrs. Langtry, but can't say so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll send her right up. Roy goes back to the elevator. Simms continues his monologue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had my first hotel thirty-seven years ago in Wichita Falls, Texas, and that's where I began to learn about women. They just don't make the money, you see, not regular they don't, and there's only one way they can get it. Roy enters the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, that Mr. Dillon there, that's the fine type of person I have in mind for here. Like yourself, I have no doubt. He's a salesman, regular as clockwork, has a suite here. Fine man. Now, about these women. At first, you know, they just go out and do it now and then, just enough to make ends meet. But pretty soon they got that bank open twenty-four hours a day, and then you've got trouble. Hookers and hotellin' just don't mix. You'd think the cops'd be too busy catching real criminals, not snooping around after working girls, but that's the way the gravy stains, as the saying is, and I don't fight it. An ounce of prevention is my motto. Myra enters from the front, looks across at Simms, points upward. Simms calls to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes, Mrs. Langtry, he's up there, he's expecting you. Myra crosses to the elevator. Simms speaks more softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you keep out the women in the first place, see, you keep out the hookers, and then you keep out the cops, and that's how you have a clean place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: along the balcony, with Roy's apartment door in f.g. and Los Angeles in b.g. Myra crosses to the door, opens it with her key, enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small crowded old-fashioned bathroom. Roy, shirt open and trousers pushed down almost to his crotch, looks in the mirror at purplish greenish bruises on his stomach. He touches his stomach, winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy? He looks at the door, then grins at his reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your medicine is here. He leaves the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hotel furniture, shabby and anonymous. On the walls, contrasting with everything else, are two crying-clown pictures on black velvet, mounted in big boxy frames. Myra stands in the middle of the room, and Roy enters, shirt and trousers still disarranged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, well. In a real hurry, are we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always, for you, baby. He reaches for her, but she playfully holds him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You aren't taking me for granted, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taking you for granite? He grins, as his fingertip prods her breast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That isn't granite. If that fell on me, it wouldn't hurt at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly's white Chrysler is parked next to an open-air phone. Traffic whizzes by. Lilly talks on the phone, with pen and notebook at the ready. The racetrack is visible in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm done here. Do I come back to Baltimore?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It could be an expensive, if gaudy, lawyer's office. Baltimore harbor is visible past the windows. IRV, the accountant, sits at a desk covered -- but neatly covered -- with ledgers, computer printouts, etc. He speaks on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobo wants you to go on to Delmar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delmar? I never go out to California. That's a thousand miles from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nine hundred. Bobo needs somebody to handle playback this time. Come on, Lilly, you don't argue with Bobo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take two, three days. Call when you get there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I'll swing around Los Ang gleez on the way. This is Lilly making the best of the situation. She listens a bit more, GRUNTS a farewell, hangs up, moves to her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, anonymous hotel furniture. Roy and Myra naked in bed, he on his back, she straddling him, both moving gently. He's half feeling pleasure, half unconscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I am, baby, believe me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy? It this all we have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All? It ain't bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more than this? He tries to concentrate on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking abut, Myra? Marriage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't say that. You aren't marriage material. He keeps watching her, ironic, hips moving. Looking for a distraction, she notices the bruise on his stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that? She touches it; he flinches back, in real pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow! Hey, what are you trying to do, throw me off my game?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, baby. Come to Mama. She folds forward onto him. He puts his arms around her. They rock together slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The same mountains in b.g. as at the track. Lilly carries two small bags from her motel room, puts them on the back seat of the Cadillac, gets behind the wheel, drives away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra, dressed, primps at the mirror, surveys herself critically, is reasonably satisfied, leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy lies supine on the bed, semi-conscious, half-covered by a sheet. Myra, casual, not noticing his condition, leans her head in through the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wore you out, did I? It's a good woman you can't keep down, baby. He moves fitfully, CROAKS an attempt at speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a good sleep, baby. Call you tomorrow. He sits up, trying to grin and be easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait'll next year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: across Roy's profile, with open bedroom door beyond him. Through it, the living room and outer door can be seen. Myra crosses the living room, opens the door. Bright sunlight pours in, emphasizing the sweat on his face. She closes the door, and he gives up trying to smile. Gingerly, he touches his bruised stomach, winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn that guy. He's going to get out of bed, but movement creates pain. He sits back against the headboard, looks around, reaches painfully to the bedside table drawer, takes a quarter from it, studies the quarter, feels it with fingertips, places it on the back of his left hand, slowly moves the soft pads of his right palm over it, then turns the quarter over and repeats. Then he takes the quarter in his right hand, flips it, slaps it down onto the back of his left hand, SPEAKS simultaneously with the hands coming together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smack. He looks away, right hand moving minimally on left hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heads. He lifts the right hand, nods, then flips the coin again, looks away, moves the right hand slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heads. Again he's right. Again he repeats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tails. He's about to repeat when a wave of weakness comes over him. He sits back, gasping, but won't acknowledge the problem. He forces himself to flip the coin, misses catching it, finds it on the blanket, flips it again, slaps it onto the back of the other hand, looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tails. Right again. He prepares to flip the coin, but then his hand sags onto the covers, his chin drops, his eyes glaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much can I bet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train runs through a forest, tree shadows making a light and-dark pattern. Roy, four or five years younger, sits with a three-core-monte gang, consisting of a DEALER, a spectacled
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: beside him, Roy facing the dealer, a ROPER next to Roy. On a briefcase on the dealer's lap are three cards, face up: An ace and two deuces. Across the aisle, alone in the seats, sits MINTZ, a conman in his fifties, pretending not to watch, but watching with amusement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's between you two. I got nothing at stake here, I'm just dealing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if we both guess wrong? You aren't gonna take... The dealer turns aside, allowing himself to be distracted. He and the shill ARGUE nonsensically. The roper nudges Roy, then reaches out and crimps the ace. Roy's doing a wide-eyed bumpkin kid; he stares at the roper in delight and amazement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the shill, arguing with the dealer but looking toward Roy and the roper, then increasing the force of his argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: across the amused Mintz at the roper whispering to Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , Roy and the roper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got him now! Put down that big bill you got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fifty or the hundred?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hundred! Hurry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ace is what I want? The roper's having trouble keeping his patience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure it is!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , the dealer and the shill, fake-squabbling, Roy and the roper seen in b.g. between their faces, Roy finally bringing out his wallet, withdrawing a bill. Relieved, the dealer and the shill cut the crap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the group as Roy puts his hundred dollar bill on the briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that okay? The shill pulls a messy wad of bills from his inner pocket, uses most of it to cover the bet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're damn right that's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoever finds the ace, wins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the dealer's hands, shuffling the cards at lightning speed. He deals the cards out face down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy's sweat-covered face, eyelids fluttering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the group. Roy squints at the cards, light and dark playing on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too dark. I just can't see. Casually, but too quickly to be stopped, he reaches across and plucks the shill's glasses off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me borrow these, will you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: across Mintz, surprised and amused, at the group in b.g., in consternation as Roy puts on the glasses and looks down at the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, that's better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The glasses are 'readers.' Through them, a large gray 'A' can be seen on the back of one of the non-crimped cards. Roy's hand reaches out and flips it over. It's the ace of spades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: across Roy toward the doorway. Roy, eyes closed, smiles in triumph, then winces in pain. Mintz partially appears, hovering beside the bed, grinning at Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't teach you that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You taught me a lot. Then I invented.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Weary bored people sit around waiting. Roy, 17, lugging a big suitcase, walks through, takes a seat near Mintz, who's doing card tricks for his own pleasure. Roy watches, then moves closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me see how you did that one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scram. Go home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't. I just left home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're too young. You should be in school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am in school. Mintz peers at him, taking an interest. Then he holds up the five of spades, shows it to Roy, puts it back in the deck, shuffles, shows Roy the deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's the five?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In your other hand. Mintz grins slowly, turns his hand over with the palmed card showing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM NIGHT Roy slumps, eyes closed, half-smiling, with the fever Mintz hovering. Roy's smile fades, his fluttering eyelids grow still, his face slack. The fever Mintz fades and disappears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a large sign indicating "Los Angeles" straight ahead. CAMERA PANS DOWN and around 180 degrees to face the several lanes of heavy Los Angeles-bound traffic. LONG BEAT. Hundreds of cars rush by. CAMERA PANS with Lilly's white Chrysler as it comes along in the stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: through the Chrysler's left side window at Lilly, driving, concentrating, biting her left thumbnail. She becomes aware that's what she's doing, shakes her head in irritation: She's trying to break herself of this habit. Ostentatiously she tucks the thumb into her fist, rests the fist on top of the steering wheel, where she can keep an eye on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the westbound lanes. The Chrysler passes. Soon it's out of sight among all the other cars. LONG BEAT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: across the unmoving unconscious Roy toward the doorway. The apartment door beyond the living room opens, throwing light on Roy, who doesn't react. Lilly enters, in silhouette, closes the door, crosses toward the bedroom. (Until she speaks, we can't be quite sure who this is. With the similarity between herself and Myra, this could be Myra.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy? No reaction. Lilly, getting worried, moves closer, through the bedroom doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy? You asleep? His head moves slightly. He barely has strength to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra? She moves forward to the side of the bed, only her torso IN FRAME. She touches a hand to his forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My God! She turns, hurries back to the living room, looks around for the phone, crosses to it, dials, SPEAKS. Roy's eyes open, he frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly, hard and fast and urgent, on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell the doctor I work for Bobo Justus, and this is an emergency. Don't worry, he knows who Bobo is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: down toward Roy, from above, he's weak but troubled. Eyes closed, frowning, whispering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go away, Lilly. Go away. Roy's eyes close. He looks dead. SLOW FADE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The DOCTOR, a nervous heavyset man in his fifties, a drinker from the look of him, is on the phone in b.g., while Lilly prowls the room, looking at everything with distaste, then stopping to frown at the box-framed clown pictures. She doesn't get it. She touches one of the pictures, trying to understand. The doctor hangs up, turns to Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ambulance is on the way, for what good it will do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? He's going to be all right!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Dillon, your son was in some sort of accident. He's had an internal hemorrhage, he's bleeding to death inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, make it stop!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His blood pressure is under a hundred. I don't think he'll live to get to the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know who I work for. He's uncomfortable, wants to dismiss that part of his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes, but that's -- LILLY My son will be all right. If he isn't, I'll have you killed. The doctor stares at her in astonishment, then in belief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of ambulance siren. To break the moment, he crosses to the door, opens it. Light bathes Lilly. The doctor steps back across the threshold, waiting for the ambulance. He looks back at Lilly, who stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, skin pallid, eyes closed and sunken, lips white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of siren LOUDER. SOUND SEGUES to CHILD CRYING. CRYING FADES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A clumsy slum hotel fifteen years ago, with a tiny lobby, the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at a half-door in one wall. Lilly, at 24, enters from the street. This is a definite hooker, with bright maroon hair and a black-and-white miniskirt. She stops wordlessly at the desk for her key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your kid's in the back here. He's crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy? He's always crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids beat him up, because his home life is, uh, different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like you, too. The clerk shrugs. He doesn't like this tough broad. He turns and calls back into his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, your mother's here. Roy, 10, comes reluctantly out to Lilly, sniffling and rubbing his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's your story today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They twisted my arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only one arm? He tries not to cry, and shows her a space between his teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They knocked out my tooth!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only one tooth? Roy's frustrated, unhappy, having nowhere else to turn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You always say that! Lilly won't take him seriously, but she relents enough to stop teasing him, and to pat his head, ignoring how he flinches away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, kid, let's see if there's any food in the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hah. Lilly gives him a jaundiced look, walks Roy to the stairs and up. The clerk, scornful but sexually interested, watches her go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy in a hospital bed, with more color in his face, breathing more normally. He begins to react to the sound of people speaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, really, you're Roy's mother? That's impossible!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not quite. But I'm not sure who you are, Mrs... Langtry, was it? Roy's eyes open, he looks toward the voices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Roy's friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , Lilly and Myra facing one another across the foot of Roy's bed, in a two-bed hospital room. (The OLD MAN in the other bed sleeps through the scene.) Neither woman is yet aware that Roy's awake. Lilly looks Myra up and down, with obvious contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I imagine you're lots of people's friend. Myra moves one pace to the side, studying Lilly's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, of course, now that I see you in the light, you're plenty old enough to be Roy's mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't we all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Play nice. Don't fight. The women, startled, both move toward Roy, one on each side of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , Myra and Lilly both leaning over to look down at Roy's sleepy face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy. You're going to be all right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure I am. What made you turn up, after all these years?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm working down in San Diego. Just for a few weeks. (awkward laugh) Thought I'd drop in on my long-lost son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to see you. (turns to Myra) What am I doing in here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were bleeding inside, honey. Remember that bruise you had?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You called the doctor, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, no, Roy. Your mother found you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah? (very casual, to Lilly) Thanks. (back to Myra) How long do they say I'm in here? Myra's willing to fight with Lilly, but Roy's attitude toward his mother makes her uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy... Your mom saved your life. Roy turns his head, gives Lilly an ironic smile. Lilly waits, holding herself in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? Only one life? She nods, accepting that, but then responds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second time I gave it to you. Roy gives her a cold smile, then turns to Myra for the ironic explanation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was kind of... inconvenient... for Lilly. Lilly has nothing but contempt for Myra. To be humiliated in front of Myra -- and by her son -- is the worst thing that could happen to her. She makes as dignified an exit as she can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... You're all right now, I guess. I have to get down to the track.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, uh, Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't mention it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I owe you my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You always did. Lilly exits. Myra looks after her, curious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Down to the track?" Roy will not talk about this, with anyone. His response is cold, closing the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to know everything about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do. And once I'm out of here, I'll remind you of the best parts. They smile flirtatiously at one another, both with their minds on other things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very messy, small. Myra showers. She finishes, emerges, wraps herself in a towel, opens the crowded messy medicine cabinet, removes cosmetics and other items, starts to tweeze her eyebrows. Doorbell RINGS. She looks irritated, ignores it. Long doorbell RING. Exasperated, she slaps the tweezers down, exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another furnished apartment, this one with Myra's clothing and dishes and glasses and other junk all over it. She crosses to the door, pulls it open. The APARTMENT MANAGER enters; a sullen, nervous, heavyset man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard the shower, didn't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care about that. This time, I gotta have the rent. Myra forces herself to be more pleasant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, I thought I was gonna be all right by now, I just need a little more -- MANAGER It isn't the owner, Myra, it's my wife. She knows what's going on. This time, I gotta have the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, you know you'll -- In gesturing, Myra "accidentally" loses the towel, then wraps it around herself again as the manager stares nervously away. She smiles, knowing she's got him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, could we talk it over? Do you want a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wife sent me here, Myra. For the money. She's waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have it tonight. Nine o'clock? Ten?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This time...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll work something out, Joe. She strokes his arm, smiling. He flees. She smiles till he's gone, then looks worried, leans her head against the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, very comfortable in pajamas and robe, sits in a wheelchair beside the bed, with magazines lying handy on the bed. Myra, irritable, paces beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see why you're still here. You look healthy to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just do what the doctor says, babe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're just comfortable, that's all. You don't even ask to go home. You just lie around, let your mama take care of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else is paying for all this? You badmouth the woman all the time, but you sure do take the payoffs she gives you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll pay Lilly back, don't you worry about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like to come here, Roy. Every time I do, your mother comes in and makes remarks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just Lilly's way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you never defend me. You're afraid of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, don't be stupid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a mama's boy, if you want the truth. This is so absurd, Roy doesn't know how to respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you kid --? I hadn't even seen her in seven years! Lilly enters, smiling in self-confidence. A large ugly burn is on the back of her right hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should my ears be burning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They might as well. Lilly gives her a mock-admiring look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard those skirts were coming back. Myra's not quite up to direct confrontation with Lilly. She glowers at Roy instead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get well soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every day in every way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see you when you get home. Myra stalks out. Acting as though Myra hadn't existed, Lilly puts her bag on the bed, takes mail from it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to your hand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a little accident. I went by your place, picked up your mall. Just bills, I'll take care of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can take care of my own bills, Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you say. The manager says your boss called. (crooked grin) Really pulled the wool over everybody's eyes, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? So I've got a job. So what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop kidding me! Four years in a town like Los Ang-gleez, and a peanut selling job is the best you can do? You expect me to believe that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's there. The boss called, you said so yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that dump you live in! Those clown pictures on the walls! This reference alerts and worries Roy, which he tries to hide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like those.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do not! Roy Dillon? Cornball clown pictures? Commission salesman? It's all a front, isn't it? You're on the grift, I know you are. You're working some angle, and don't tell me you're not because I wrote the book!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're one to talk. Still running playback money for the mob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's me. That's who I am. You were never cut out for the rackets, Roy, and if you -- ROY How come? She considers him. His expression is jaunty, daring her. She gives him a somber answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You aren't tough enough. He's afraid she's right. He covers the doubt with a display of self-assurance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not as tough as you, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. And you have to be. She holds up her burned hand, showing it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You asked me about this. You really want to know what happened? He isn't sure he does; but what choice does he have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My boss is a guy named Bobo Justus, back in Baltimore. When a long shot gets too much action, I have to put money on that horse at the track, because it's the only way to get the odds down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first day of the Delmar meet, there was a nag called Bluebell. I should have been on it. But that was the day after you came in here, so I stuck around to see how you were gonna be. He would speak protest, deny, explain, but she cuts him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was my choice, nothing to do with you. I took a chance, and it didn't work out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bluebell came in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sent Bobo ten grand of my own money, like it was the winnings from my bets. I hoped that would cover me. (shrug) It didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DELMAR DAY AN ANGLE on the exit doors toward the parking lot. Lilly comes out, self-absorbed, then sees something ahead of her, falters briefly, keeps walking, tries a very shaky smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , as Lilly approaches her car. BOBO JUSTUS, 50, a blunt hoodlum in a good suit and a civilized veneer, stands leaning against the car, arms folded, squinting behind sunglasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Bobo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I buy you that dress, you piece of shit? Lilly's scared, startled, but trying to figure out how to play this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I guess so. You're the guy I work for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You work for me, huh? Then I just may flush you down the toilet. Drive me to the Durando. Bobo gets into the passenger seat, while Lilly nods convulsive agreement and hurries around to get behind the wheel. The car jolts forward, then smooths, and heads for the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Driving along the highway. Lilly concentrates on traffic. Bobo heavily watches her profile, finally speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bluebell. Lilly's eyes briefly close, her shoulders sag. Then she goes back to the silent alert person she'd been. Bobo nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you figure you were gonna get away with that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not getting away with anything, Bobo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're fuckin right you're not. How much did your pals cut you in for on that nag, huh? Or did they give you the same kind of screwing you gave me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was down on that horse, Bobo. Not as much as I should have been, but there was a lot of action on those-- Bobo taps a fingertip against the side of her head to shut her up. She shuts up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to keep my teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I'll ask you another. You think I got no contacts out here? That nag paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the tote board from the time the odds were posted. There ain't enough action to tickle the tote, but you claim a ten grand win! You send me ten thousand dollars, like I'm some mark you can blow off!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobo, no, I -- BOBO You wanna talk to me straight up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My son -- BOBO Your what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My son was in the hospital -- BOBO What the fuck are you doin with a son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He left home a long time ago. He was in the hospital, up in Los Ang gleez, real sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Motherhood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never fucked up before, Bobo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You expect me to buy this? It's time for Lilly to show tough, and she knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do buy it, Bobo. I cost you, and I'm sorry. Bobo thinks this over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a lot of people work for me, Lilly. I can't have shit like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll never happen again. I swear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It happened once. With me, that's making a habit of it. Lilly drops back to her final position; fatalism.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're calling the shots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got any kind of long coat in the car? Anything you can wear home over your clothes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll loan you a raincoat. Lilly drives, holding herself together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tall expensive hotel on the coast north of San Diego.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S with the Chrysler pulling in and stopping at the entrance, then PANS UP the balconied facade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Living room of a high-floor suite. CAMERA FACES across the room to the balcony and the view of the ocean. Entrance door to one side. A supermarket shopping bag is on the coffee table. Two THUGS sit on the sofa, watching TV. The door opens and Lilly enters, followed by Bobo. The thugs immediately rise and switch off the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a walk. The thugs leave the room as Lilly crosses to stand between US and the view, followed by Bobo, neither looking out. Lilly turns to Bobo, who abruptly punches her hard in the stomach. She falls to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Bobo steps across her and goes over to close the drapes over the view. Lilly sits up, watching him, waiting obediently. Bobo looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get me a bath towel. She gets up, hurting, and hurries to the bathroom. Bobo sits on the sofa, crosses his ankles on the coffee table next to the supermarket bag. He takes out and lights a cigar. Lilly comes back with a large white bath towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ever hear about the oranges?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, the insurance frammis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about the oranges, Lilly. He kicks over the supermarket bag. Oranges roll on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While you put those in the towel. Lilly's very scared. She drops to her knees, spreads the towel, crawls around gathering oranges while she talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hit a person with the oranges in the towel, they get big, awful looking bruises, but they don't really get hurt, not if you do it right. It's for working scams against insurance companies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if you do it wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can louse up your insides. You can get puh, puh, puh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that, Lilly? Lilly pauses, bent over, tightly holding an orange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Permanent damage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never shit right again. He gets to his feet, leaving his cigar in an ashtray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring me the towel. Fumbling slightly, she folds the towel edges together to make a bag, then stands, brings the towel to Bobo. He makes a production out of getting his grip on the edges just right. She stands as limp as she can, just wanting to get through this. He looks at her without expression, rears back with the towel, swings it forward, lets it drop open. Oranges roll on the floor. Lilly stares, wide-eyed, recognizing reprieve. Bobo tosses the towel behind him onto the sofa, then gestures contemptuously for her to pick up the oranges again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , closer, as Lilly turns, bending toward the oranges, and Bobo picks up his cigar, then lifts a foot and kicks her flatfooted, hard, in the back. She sprawls on the floor. He follows and drops to his knees on her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: close on Lilly on the floor, Bobo's knees grinding back and forth into her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Bobo, grimacing as he bears down, pressing his weight onto her back. He leans forward, left hand bracing himself on the floor beside her head as he reaches down with the cigar held in his right hand and presses the ember against the back of her splayed-out right hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly, clenching her teeth, tears squeezing from her eyes, simply bearing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Bobo, catching a bad smell, looking back down behind himself at Lilly's body. This is the result he wanted, but it disgusts him. He straightens up, still kneeling on her, puts the cigar in his mouth, doesn't like its taste, removes it, braces his left hand against her back while he lifts off her, getting back up onto his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , Bobo stepping over her, expression repulsed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go clean yourself up. He puts the cigar back in the ashtray as she rises, cradling her burnt hand. Not looking toward Bobo, hobbling with knees together, she starts from the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The raincoat's on the bed. She leaves. He opens the drapes, then picks up an orange from the floor and steps out onto the balcony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobo stands looking out at the ocean. He enjoys breathing the sea air. He slowly peels the orange, dropping pieces of peel over the side. Lilly appears in the doorway, wearing a too-large man's raincoat. Bobo doesn't seem to notice her at first, then nods to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost forgot. That ten grand of yours. It's in the envelope by the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thanks, Bobo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gee, I better not, if it's okay. I still gotta drive back up to Los Ang-gleez.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See your son, huh? Well, that's nice. A side of you I didn't know, Lilly. Lilly chances taking a step out onto the balcony. It's vital that she encourage this forgive-and-forget dialogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a good kid. A salesman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the square, huh? And how are you making out these days? Stealing much? Bobo's being jolly now. Lilly's scared, but has to be jolly, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From you? My folks didn't raise any stupid kids. Bobo's joshing now. He raises a humorous eyebrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not skimming a thing, Lilly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. Take a little, leave a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a thousand percent right!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or else he's working an angle. If he doesn't steal a little, he's steeling big.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know it, Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I like that suit, Bobo. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look taller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you can tell them I said they're right. (looks at sky) I better get going. Roy'll wonder where I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will. So long, Bobo. Lilly leaves the balcony. Bobo eats more orange, looking out at the ocean. His expression is stern but calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly drives along the highway, weeping, shaking, teeth chattering. Her hands are both high on the wheel, the back of the right hand developing a large red burn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucky! Lucky! Oh, am I lucky.! Am I lucky!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy's appalled and embarrassed and ashamed by this story; the surface result is, he's mad at Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucky? You call that lucky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He let me live. He let me be his friend. Roy in his agitation wheels himself back and forth in the wheelchair, bumping into things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't put up with that! Nobody has to put up with that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do if you're where I am. Where you want to be. How'd you get that punch in the stomach, Roy? He closes down, sullen, not caring if she believes him or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tripped over a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get off the grift, Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have the stomach for it. He stares at her, hurt and angry. She stares back, unflinching. Angrily, he spins the wheelchair around, his back to her. Now she's hurt. She shrugs, speaks indifferently to his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just give you your life. What you do with it is up to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. She hesitates, then stalks out, shutting the door. Hearing the door close, Roy spins around in the wheelchair to face where she'd been. He starts to get up, pauses midway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angry, Lilly takes a step away from the closed door, then stops, looks uncertainly back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, on his feet now, stands still, indecisive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly shakes her head, turns firmly away, marches down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

When you're cleaning those bathrooms, what you do, you pick up the towel, you give it a good shake and a good look, and you say to yourself, 'Would I dry myself on this towel?' If the answer's yes, fold it. Roy comes out of the elevator, crossing toward Simms.

direction.raw_text: That's true, Mr. Simms.

direction.raw_text: We never know when and we never know why. We never know how. The only blessed thing we know is, it'll be at the most inconvenient and unexpected time. Just when you've got tickets to the World Series. And that's the way the permanent waves.

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm back now. I just wanted you to know. Gotta rush.

direction.raw_text: Happy to see you looking so good. Roy crosses back to the elevator, enters it. Elevator door closes. Simms looks after him, avuncular.

direction.raw_text: That fellow could be a congressman. (turns to maid) If it's wet, you don't fold it. You shake it, and hang it neatly on the rod provided.

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.

direction.raw_text: & WEBB - DAY A long low stucco building in an industrial section of Los Angeles. The company name is on the glass of the main door.

direction.raw_text: a humorless hotshot of 28, dressed in short-sleeved white shirt and narrow dark tie, prowls the cracked sidewalk in front of the place, MAKING REMARKS into a small cassette recorder. Roy's Honda arrives and drives into the company lot at the end of the building. Kaggs watches, then goes on patrolling and TALKING into the recorder. Roy comes out to the sidewalk and heads for the entrance. Kaggs stops and watches him approach.

direction.raw_text: Whadaya say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. Roy continues on and enters the building.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: typing or adding up figures or TALKING on the phone. Beyond them are floor-to-ceiling bins and shelves with narrow aisles between, in which more CLERKS move busily, filling orders or doing inventory. A great sense of activity and hubbub. Roy enters, looks around in surprise. A clerk at a front desk sees him, stands happily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy! Welcome back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on? This is usually coffee break time.

direction.raw_text: Not since Kaggs showed up. Other clerks, aware of Roy, come over with AD LIB GREETINGS.

direction.raw_text: Hey, yeah, I'm fine, everything's great. What's this Kaggs? Sounds like a disease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Troubleshooter from the main office. Came out here right after you went into the hospital, and he ain't had a kind word for anybody yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody knows anything but him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chopped off half a dozen salesmen; won't wholesale to them any more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of sense does that make? They're all on commission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think he'll chop me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he does, he's crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here he comes! The clerks all hurry back to their desks as Kaggs enters. He crosses to Roy, hand stuck out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kaggs. Home office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy Dillon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that. Knew it when I saw you out there. The best salesman here, which isn't saying much. Want to talk to you, Dillon. Kaggs moves toward the gate in the rail, still holding Roy's hand, to move him along. Roy stands still, which yanks Kaggs back. Kaggs frowns at him, releases his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was a pretty backhanded compliment. If I let people get away with things like that, I wouldn't be a good salesman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. I apologize. But I still want to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lead on. Kaggs leads the way through the rail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Small, crowded, efficient, with interior windows showing the aisles of bins. Kaggs leads Roy in, shuts the door, gestures at the second chair as he goes behind the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a seat. They both sit, Roy amused and observant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Makes no difference to me if they're only on commission. If they don't make good money, they're not giving us good representation, and we can't afford to have them around. Ever supervise salesmen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, you've had to supervise yourself. This place needs a sales manager. Somebody who's proved he's a salesman and can handle other salesmen. He'd have a lot of deadwood to clear out, new men to hire. What do you think? Roy doesn't yet know he's being offered the job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like a good Idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know offhand what your best year's been, we can look it up. The idea is, we'll top it by fifteen percent. Now Roy gets it. He's startled, almost scared, thinks automatically of escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just the first year. If you aren't worth a lot more than that the second year, I'll kick you out. What do you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, uh... No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't take that job! I mean, I mean, I can't take it right away. I'm still recuperating, I just dropped in to say hello, see everybody -- KAGGS I didn't realize. Yeah, you do look a little pale. How soon will you be ready? A week?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you need a man right now. It wouldn't be fair to you to -- KAGGS I take care of the being-fair-to-me department. Things've gone to hell this long, they can go a little longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... Kaggs gets to his feet, terminating the meeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you in a week, Roy. I can call you Roy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, sure. Fine. Kaggs sticks his hand out for another shake. Roy obliges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm Perk. Short for Percy, I'm afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy's place. Roy enters from the bedroom, carrying a suitcase, which he drops on the sofa. He goes to one of the box-framed clown pictures, takes it off the wall, puts it face down on the coffee table, removes two wing nuts holding the back, lifts off the back, and reveals stacks of money hidden inside. He takes two wads of money out, counting them, putting them on the coffee table, then fits the back in place, reattaches the wing nuts, and hangs the picture on the wall. Stuffing the wads of money into the suitcase, he leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cab pulls up to discharge passengers. Roy and the DRIVER get out. Roy pays the driver, who opens the trunk to take out several pieces of luggage. Myra leans hesitantly out, as though afraid it's raining out there.

direction.raw_text: This really is it. Union Station. Myra comes out of the cab. She's feeling testy. Roy's in a good mood and ignores her bad temper.

direction.raw_text: I don't see why we have to take the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Big spender.

direction.raw_text: You ain't seen nothin.

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN DAY AN ANGLE from outside the passenger car through the window at Myra, mulish, watching the scenery go by. Beyond her Roy's easy, content. He moves to get up.

direction.raw_text: , within the train. Myra looks questioningly at Roy as he stands.

direction.raw_text: Stretch my legs. Come along? She's not ready to relent and enjoy herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.

direction.raw_text: See you soon. He walks down the aisle behind Myra, who sighs and looks out the window again.

direction.raw_text: Oh! Ow, I'm sorry! Oh, look, I spilled your drinks!

direction.raw_text: A brightly lit Hopperish place. Lilly sits alone in a booth eating a bowl of chili and reading a newspaper folded beside the bowl. A DRUNK with a great deal of faith in his own charm sits with a male FRIEND at the counter, drinking coffee. The drunk keeps looking toward Lilly, grinning, COMMENTING playfully to his friend, who's bored by it all. Lilly doesn't seem to be aware of him. The drunk rises from his stool, turning toward Lilly, staggering slightly. His friend makes a small move to stop him, then shrugs and lets him go. The drunk makes his way to Lilly's table, leans on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty woman like you shouldn't eat alone. Whadaya wanna eat alone for? Lilly gives him a flat look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go away. She looks past him toward the WAITRESS behind the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I have some coffee, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could have coffee together. My name's Kenny. Lilly looks over at the drunk's friend, who pointedly ignores the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your pal wants you. The drunk could turn mean; his gesture brushing away the idea of his friend is stronger than necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him find his own pretty woman. The waitress arrives, with the coffee pot and a mug. She puts the mug on the table, pours coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This fellow bothering you, Ma'am?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go sit down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll sit here. Move over. The drunk wants to sit beside Lilly, who looks to the waitress to solve the problem, but the waitress stands there with the coffee pot, looking helpless. The drunk bends to slide onto the seat. Lilly, exasperated, rabbit punches him in the throat. The drunk, astounded and in pain (and not breathing), staggers back, flailing, hitting the waitress's arm so that she slops coffee on him as his feet tangle and he falls heavily onto the floor. Lilly, suddenly concerned, slides out of the booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh! Are you all right? She goes to one knee beside the drunk, who clutches his own throat with both hands, retching as he tries to inhale. Lilly looks up at the astonished waitress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shouldn't have hit him that hard. I guess I don't know my own strength. The drunk's friend arrives and helps Lilly get the drunk to his feet. The drunk is breathing now, but shaken. He looks at Lilly with reproachful eyes. His friend transfers his annoyance at the drunk to Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't have to do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I did. You should take better care of your friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outta here. The drunk and his friend head for the exit, as Lilly turns to the waitress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry a lady can't eat in here without being bothered. The waitress is apologetic, and also in awe of Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It won't happen again, Ma'am, I promise. Dinner's on the house. More chili? Dessert? We have lovely pecan pie, my husband makes it himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sounds nice. Pecan pie. Thank you. Lilly sits down as the waitress goes back behind the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the waitress, as she puts down the coffee pot, brings out the pecan pie, prepares to slice it, pauses, looks with wonder toward Lilly.

direction.raw_text: The setting is a wide porch or lanai pretending to be a 19th century locale; a mix of western and antebellum south; the usual tourist confusion of histories. The effect is both romantic and false. Roy and Myra linger over wine, near the end of their meal. Roy's relaxed, happy, expansive. Myra's pleased but watchful, the bird watching the worm.

direction.raw_text: You were right, I had to get out of that hospital. Nothing wrong with me any more.

direction.raw_text: I'll sign that affidavit.

direction.raw_text: Great to get away, take it easy. Next week, I'll get back to work.

direction.raw_text: Oh, come on, Roy. She mimes rolling the die, slowly, showing how it will roll out of her hand just so, then speaks to him as though to a bright child.

direction.raw_text: The tap. What you do for a living.

direction.raw_text: You're on the grift. Same as me.

direction.raw_text: Myra, I'm not following this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, you're a short-con operator. And a good one, I think. Don't talk to me like I'm another square. Roy leans back, studying her, thinking it over, makes up his mind.

direction.raw_text: You talk the lingo. What's your pitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The long end. Big con.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody does that single-o.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was teamed ten years with the best in the business. Cole Langley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've heard the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was beautiful. And getting better all the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is, Roy! And now, right now, it's the perfect time, the best time since I've been in the game.

direction.raw_text: New skyscrapers are separated by blank fields or small older buildings. Almost no traffic. A white limo drives alone down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All over the southwest, you've got these businessmen, they were making money when everybody was making money, they think that means they're smart.

direction.raw_text: Myra, dressed expensively and fashionably, sits with
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a stocky businessman, sixtyish. Their manner suggests intimacy.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hops out and holds the door as Myra and Hebbing emerge and cross to enter the building, Myra carrying an attache case.

direction.raw_text: They still got money, but they need more money, and that's just the kind of guy Cole and me like.

direction.raw_text: This building has a central atrium with corridors circling it, waist-high walls on the atrium side, glass-walled elevators rising up through the atrium. Myra and Hebbing are visible in an elevator coming up to a high floor. It stops and they exit, moving down the corridor.

direction.raw_text: When the oil money was good, they put up all these office buildings, and now they're half empty.

direction.raw_text: translucent glass in door with company name: COE, STARK, FELLOWES & ASSOCIATES, STOCK BROKERAGE - London - New York - Dallas - Los Angeles - Tokyo. CAMERA PANS to follow Myra and Hebbing as they enter the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: showing the well-furnished outer office, the attractive and competent RECEPTIONIST welcoming Myra as someone she knows, gesturing her through, Myra graciously accepting, moving on. Hebbing's impressed by everything, trying not to show it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll give you anything to move in; first two months free, redecoration, whatever you want.

direction.raw_text: in a clerical office, four CLERKS at well-equipped desks with computer terminals, hard at work. Maps and clocks on the walls indicate the world. Myra and Hebbing pass through.

direction.raw_text: They help you set up the store!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the PRIVATE SECRETARY'S office, she on the phone, nodding and smiling at Myra and waving her through. Myra leads the way, opening a door marked HENRY FELLOWES, Partner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm the roper, I go out and find them and bring them in. Cole ran the store, and he was the best.

direction.raw_text: Myra and Hebbing enter an office decorated with sleekly understated opulence; the view through large windows is of apparently-prosperous skyscrapers. Cole, a plausible rich businessman, happily greets Myra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Beth! As beautiful as ever. He lifts a dubious eyebrow toward Hebbing.

direction.raw_text: I see you brought a friend. As Mary Beth, Myra has a faint southern-belle accent and a clinging flirtatiousness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Hebbing is my bodyguard, my strong right arm. Gloucester Hebbing, may I present my fine stockbroker, Henry Fellowes. The men shake hands, Hebbing open and pleased and dignified, Cole clearly holding something back.

direction.raw_text: Mary Beth, what we have here, uh...

direction.raw_text: Oh, I told Mister Hebbing all about it, how brilliant you are at making money for your special clients!

direction.raw_text: Well, of course not! I know how dangerous this is. But I would trust Mister Hebbing with anything. (to Hebbing; suggestive) Wouldn't I, darling? While Hebbing looks manly and flustered and pleased, Cole brings from under his desk a partially full gray canvas sack marked Federal Reserve Bank.

direction.raw_text: Goody! Myra opens her attache case on the desk. Cole takes banded stacks of bills from the sack, packs them neatly in the case. Hebbing tries not to look envious and impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The top bill in each stack is a hundred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Myra takes a stack, riffles it for Hebbing's benefit.

direction.raw_text: Isn't that just beautiful?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it is. Myra returns the stack to the case, talks to Cole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry, next time, couldn't Mister Hebbing -- COLE (shocked) Mary Beth! This has never been anything but -- MYRA Oh, I know, I know, and you've been wonderful since I was widowed. But Mister Hebbing has-- (to Hebbing)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: you don't mind my telling him, darling -- (to Cole)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: suffered reverses. If he could... She gestures vaguely, unable to describe the situation accurately. Hebbing fills in, bluff and hearty.

direction.raw_text: Top up the tanks, as It were. Until this little glitch in the oil economy comes to an end. (man to man laugh) Not that I understand exactly what you do, not from Mary Beth's explanation. Cole broods, studying Hebbing, deciding at last to trust him.

direction.raw_text: Well. If Mary Beth vouches for you, and if she told you the story already...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So here we are!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Hebbing, we are talking about breaking the law here, I want to be sure you understand that. No one gets hurt, but the law does get broken.

direction.raw_text: Well, that's what the law's for, isn't it?

direction.raw_text: And I don't just mean the SEC. We could have the FBI breathing down our necks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I certainly hope not.
