direction.raw_text: I can keep my mouth shut, Mister Fellowes. Describing the scheme, Cole becomes increasingly enthusiastic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, then. Sit down, sit down. Hebbing sits on the sofa, Myra beside him, holding his arm in both of hers. Cole paces, describing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Tokyo Exchange is nine hours ahead of us, New York one hour behind. There isn't one hour of the day when both are open. Information moves, but it has to wait. Now, we have a young fellow working here -- Do you know what a hacker is, Mister Hebbing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of those computer geniuses, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right! And this boy tapped into that main link between Tokyo and the New York Stock Exchange. He can give us, when it's really useful, a seven second delay in that movement of information. Do you know what that means? Hebbing doesn't want to admit ignorance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you've got your information ahead of New York, I see that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every once in a while, a major change comes through. We have seven seconds to take advantage, put our buy order, our sell order, into the computer in New York before the Tokyo data comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not much time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to be ready. We have to have the money, and we have to know what the information means, and we have to move immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven seconds. I don't see how you do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These machines -- They're in here. Cole crosses to an inner door, pushes it partway open, looks back grinning with his hand on the knob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want a look?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Henry, no, that's just boring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bare dusty room. A ladder leans against a wall, a paint can on the floor beside it. Only Cole is visible in the open doorway. He speaks back into the main office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come take a look. An entire-suite of main-frame computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not really interested, Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole remains in the doorway, luring Hebbing with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's quite a sight. You sure? Cole's pushing this too far. Hebbing's thinking politeness requires him to look. Myra's nervous, her smile with an edge to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry, don't try Mister Hebbing's patience. He knows what machines look like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole smiles at the empty room again, looks back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if you're sure. He shuts the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole liked to take risks, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy and Myra at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't think they were risks. He was so good, Roy, he could just play with the mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when he got serious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd explain he had to have cash, so there wouldn't be any paper trail for the SEC. And a lot of cash, or it wasn't worth while. The least we ever took was forty thousand, and the most was one hundred eighty-five thousand dollars! From one sucker!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought these people were broke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, Roy, just cash poor. They had savings accounts, stocks to sell, houses to mortgage. Sell their wife's jewelry. Oh, they had a lot of money, when they put their minds to it. Or when I put their minds to it. I stayed with them, that's the roper's job, made them get up every penny they could raise, turn it all over to Cole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a month later, the sucker calls the cops and you're on the run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No no! He never calls the cops, not after we give him the blow-off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra puts a blood-filled four-inch-square plastic package into her bra on the left side, then puts on a white blouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three or four days after Cole got the money, he'd phone the sucker, tell him he'd made the move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra and Hebbing hurry across the sidewalk from the limo, each carrying an attache case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our buy was in the computer, we were rich, he should come collect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra and Hebbing enter, Cole meets them, all happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here you are! Two rich people!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must admit, Mister Fellowes, I had moments I was worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You brought a case? Good. Cole brings out the canvas sack from under the desk, reaches in, brings out a stack of bills. The door opens and two men in suits and topcoats and hats enter, one of them flashing a badge. (These are, altered, two of the clerks from before.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold it right there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? This is a private office!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Stock fraud, tampering with Exchange communications -- Cole suddenly loses all control, becomes a gibbering wreck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my God! No! The scandal! The second man approaches Hebbing, pencil and notebook at the ready, manner cold and tough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My --? I don't I only -- COLE (screams at Myra) You! You and your goddamn big mouth!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry, no, I -- COLE Who did you tell? Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just one or two of the girls, just, they wouldn't -- Cole pulls a pistol from his desk drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't move!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Fellowes, that isn't going to do you any good. Put that down, and -- Cole ignores him, staring in frantic hatred at Myra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ruined me! You destroyed me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry, no! Cole shoots her, the SOUND very loud, the men flinching away. Myra slaps her hand to her breast; blood spurts between her fingers. In terror, she turns toward Hebbing, who stares at the blood seeping down her white blouse. She tries to speak, can't. She reaches out, her bloody hand sliding down Hebbing's front without getting any purchase, leaving a swath of blood diagonally across his jacket, shirt and tie. She topples forward. Hebbing tries to hold her, but she slips to the floor. Cole runs around the desk toward the door, waving the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back! Get back! The men warily move away from the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll kill the first one that follows me! Cole runs from the room. The two men pull guns from hip holsters under their coat-tails. Hebbing, kneeling beside Myra, watches them approach the door, crouch, run through. Hebbing rises, looks around, runs to the inner door, finds it locked. He crosses to the main door, looks out, cautiously creeps from the room. Myra sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hebbing hurries through the empty secretary's office and out the other door. The two men enter from a different door and cross to re-enter Cole's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole stands behind a pillar, watching. Across the way, Hebbing comes out of the office, staring around, trying to wipe the blood from his clothes. In obvious panic, he runs to the elevator, presses the button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: through the glass wall into the elevator as it stops. The doors open, Hebbing hurries in, frantically jabs the button. The elevator descends. CAMERA PANS to Cole coming around the corridor, entering the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General hilarity. The secretary, two men, other two clerks, chauffeur and receptionist are all present, opening champagne, Hebbing's money now out of the sack and spread on the desk. Myra, stripped to the waist (unconcerned about the others present) cleans blood from her breasts with damp towels. He and Myra look at one another across the room, broadly smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra's very up, from reliving this story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Roy, it was great! We were rolling in dough, lived wherever we wanted, only pulled two or three scams a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to Cole?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He retired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upstate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upstate where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Atascadero.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's where they keep the criminally insane, isn't it? Myra turns her face away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Expensive room. Cole, naked, expression haunted and crazed, sits cross-legged on the bed. Myra enters, happy, carrying dress shop boxes. She stops, shocked, when she sees Cole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, baby. Not again. He stares at the floor over the edge of the bed, like a shipwreck victim in a raft looking at the sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hollow. You'll fall through. Myra drops the packages on a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole, it'll be all right. Honey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just the strain again, the stress. We'll take a vacation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all hollow. Nothing behind it. She approaches him, scared but needing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole, you scare me when this happens. One of these times... She touches him. He suddenly lashes out, knocking her backward, glaring at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Demon! Demon! That's why you can walk on it! Demon!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Cole, please. Please come out of it. What would I do without you? Distracted, gone, unaware of her existence, he gazes around, hugs himself, sits staring at demons. She watches him, mournful, knowing he's gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra looks back at Roy. Her expression makes it clear she isn't going to tell him any more than she already has.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He retired, and that's it. But I didn't. I'm still the best long-con roper you'll ever see. Roy laughs, genuinely pleased by her and also tacitly letting his questions drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just bet you are, too. And now you're trying to rope me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Join up with you! I watched you, Roy, I've been watching you, wondering if I should talk about this at all, or maybe just... (shrug)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a hike, you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need a partner, Roy. I need an inside man, and you're it. You could be as wonderful as Cole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, Myra, I never had partners. I never needed them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to take soldiers for a hundred bucks. But how about taking a bank president for a hundred grand? Roy doesn't like this; he's feeling pressured. Myra sees it, but believes she's got him anyway, so she can let up. She pats his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think about it. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little drunk and happy, Roy and Myra come down the corridor together, then make it obvious they're going into separate rooms, across the corridor from one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you later. Roy complains, but half-heartedly, half humorously; this argument has already taken place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still don't see why we have to have separate rooms. You expect your father to come through?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Separate bathrooms, darling. I will not lay out all my cosmetics for you to knock over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Things a man isn't supposed to know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't mind, really, do you, Roy? It's been such a wonderful evening, I guess I just wore myself out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. I'm pretty tired myself. They unlock the opposing doors, look back at one another. Myra's smile and good-night wave are consciously cute. Roy's response is a little forced. They go into their rooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once he's alone, Roy stops trying to look like a good sport. Disgusted, he tosses the room key onto the dresser, then crosses to sliding glass doors closed in front of a balcony. He's about to close the drapes when he looks out, changes his mind, unlocks and opens the door. He steps outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A high floor, with a wide view of ocean and starry sky. Roy leans on the rail, looking out, thinking. He mutters to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long con. I'm the one's been conned. Who needs this? He continues to stand there, taking some solace from the night. BEAT. Phone RINGS. Confused, irritated, he turns to look into the room. Phone RINGS. At last, he goes back into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy crosses to pick up the phone, grumpy and suspicious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open your door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? (grins; gets it) What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open it and find out. Roy hangs up and crosses to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: directly at the door as Roy opens it, showing Myra's door open across the way, Myra standing in her doorway naked. She waves at him to move over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gangway! Roy steps back, holding his door open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: down the hall as Myra skips across from her room to Roy's, her door slamming behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra runs in, giggling. Roy shuts the door, laughing at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you don't mind, sir. I just washed my clothes, and I couldn't do a thing with them. Roy's pleased, but at a loss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You -- I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you could have seen your face when I told you good night! You looked so, so... Ah!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, come here. They embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A clean anonymous Holiday Inn. Lilly, dressed for the track, sits at the round table under the swag light, sorting through her business purse. There's a folded newspaper on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the door. She's startled. For just a second, she's like a trapped animal. Then she's calm again. She turns the purse around, opens another zipper section, removes a pistol and a silencer, quickly screws the silencer onto the pistol, lays the pistol on the table and covers it with the newspaper. Then she crosses to open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to include Roy in the doorway, grinning, easy. Lilly's surprised, pleased, but wary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy! What are you doing in San Diego?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra and me come down to LaJolla for the weekend. Lilly makes a face, but no comment, at Myra's name, as she closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you come out to the track, don't know me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We won't hit the track. The beach. Couple a nice restaurants. He takes from his pockets the wads of money held removed from the clown pictures, extends them toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four grand. For the hospital. Is that enough?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, I don't want money from you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I pay my debts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do? Since she won't take the money, he turns to put it on the table beside her purse, pushing the newspaper out of the way, revealing the gun. He gives it a surprised smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Expecting visitors?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. That was the point. She crosses to unscrew the silencer and put both pieces back in her purse. Roy, watching, points at the still angry burn on her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ought to put a bandage on that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No can do. Have to dip in and out of my bag too much. Besides, it'll heal in the air. Disdainful and hurt, she pushes at the wads of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, take that back. His own hostility shows through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. She's not used to being vulnerable, can neither hide it nor really express it; can't use it as a tactic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought... I was hoping we could play it straight with one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess not. You'll be heading east from here, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After the meet. Back to Baltimore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... nice to see you again, Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, too, Roy. Roy finds this parting unsatisfactory, but has nothing to add. With a shrug, he leaves. Lilly looks after him, her expression becoming resentful, dully angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra sits in the back seat of a taxi parked across the street from the motel. The door to Lilly's room is visible in b.g. Roy walks toward the street from Lilly's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here he comes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see him. Reaching the sidewalk, Roy turns to an empty cab parked on that side of the street, in front of the motel. Myra's driver shifts into gear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. Hold it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the guy we're following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just wait. Roy enters the other cab, which drives away, as Lilly comes out of her room in b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah. Lilly gets into her Chrysler, backs away from the slot, drives to the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we follow her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the boss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the two vehicles, as they leave the motel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the surf meets the turf. Over the punters' heads, out beyond the track, spreads the Pacific Ocean, unnoticed, ignored. In every shot in this sequence, the ocean is visible but not looked at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly, with her heavy shoulderbag, moving along empty tables, here and there picking up used tickets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Myra, on a different level, watching Lilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly at the betting windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Myra, on a high vantage point in the stands. A MAN near her watches the field through binoculars. Myra ASKS if she can borrow them for a minute. Men are always happy to do Myra favors; the man gives her the binoculars. She looks at the field briefly, then turns and looks through the binoculars the other way, outside the track. The man, surprised, looks the same way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The parking area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The man looks in curiosity at Myra, who concentrates, adjusting the focus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Foreshortened through the binoculars, Lilly opens the Chrysler's trunk, stashes money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Myra smiles, turns it into a sweet thank-you smile as she returns the binoculars to their owner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy dives into the pool, swims underwater to the ladder, climbs out near a YOUNG BLONDE on a chaise longue, who's been admiring him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You stay down real good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of my talents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother's calling. Roy looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to show Myra waving from her balcony, four flights up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Roy's at first surprised, then amused by the blonde.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naughty. He gathers up his towel and heads for the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy stands in heavy spray in the shower, half asleep, gently touching his stomach where the bruise used to be. KNOCK on door. He ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy! You drown in there? He rouses himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be right out!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myra moves away from the bathroom door. She's in a bad mood. She paces back and forth, out onto the balcony, then back into the room as Roy comes out of the bathroom wearing a towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were gone for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went out to Delmar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The track? Did you run into Lilly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She didn't see you, in other words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not trying to make trouble, Roy. It's just, she's always so nasty to me, I thought, who is she to be so high and mighty. I saw her out there, and I called a friend of mine in Baltimore, so now I know who she is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must have some very knowledgeable friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm well connected, Roy, Cole introduced me to a lot of people. Very valuable. Valuable for us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Running your broker scam, you mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and me, Roy. What a team we'll make. We think alike; we get along together. Once or twice a year we take some slob, the rest of the time we live like this. You won't regret this, Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regret what? I didn't say I was coming aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why not? I thought it was settled. What's holding you back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Myra, don't talk business here. This is time out. She considers him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, it would be too tough to give me a turndown here. Easier on home grounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes or no. They're both easier at home. Okay? Myra makes a visible effort to be accommodating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you say, darling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kaggs sits at his computer terminal, bringing up data, not pleased by what he sees. Buzzer SOUNDS. He swivels to the desk, presses the intercom button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy Dillon, Mr. Kaggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good! Send him in. With a now-we're-getting-somewhere manner, Kaggs turns back to the VDT, punches up a different set of data, sits looking at it in gloomy satisfaction. Roy enters, and Kaggs rises, extending his hand across the desk. They shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good to have you back, Roy. I was just looking at -- ROY Mr. Kaggs, I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're turning me down? Makes no sense, Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I'm just not a leader of men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, come on, Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is, Mr. Kaggs -- KAGGS Perk, remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, fine. Perk, the truth is, I like things the way they are now. Pick my own hours, have time for, uh, other activities...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A well-rounded life. I respect that. But it has to have a center, Roy, something you care about, something you can think about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I'm just not ready for that yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Roy, if that's the way you feel, I won't badger you. (forced laugh) Don't want to lose you as a salesman, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'd like to stay on. Just keep everything the way it was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what we'll do, then. But I tell you what, Roy. Before I hire anybody else, I'll ask you one last time. Fair enough?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fair enough. They shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy's room. He has one of the clown pictures face down on the coffee table. He takes money from his jacket pockets, crams it into the space, which is now just about full. As he's tightening the wing nuts closing the back, doorbell RINGS. He hurries, finishing the job, hanging the picture on the wall, then crossing to open the door. Myra enters, ebullient.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling, guess what? I had to tell you right away. She gives him an enthusiastic kiss, then marches into the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And hello to you, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I called a fellow I know in Tulsa, the one who plays my chauffeur. There's a sucker there he says is made for us. And a boroker that just shut down, we can use their office, not change a thing! Now, I can scrape up ten grand without much trouble. That leaves fifteen or twenty for your end. We could start this weekend, get the sucker into position -- ROY Wait a minute! When did this happen, that we're partners?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last I looked, we were just talking things over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the setup's there. It's there now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think I need it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're too good for the small-time, Roy. Move up to where there's big dough to be made, and you don't have to stick your neck out every day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I like it where I am. Myra's need breaks through her good sense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, maybe I don't! I had ten good years with Cole, and I want them back! I gotta have a partner! I looked and I looked and believe me, brother, I kissed a lot of fucking frogs, and you're my prince! Roy tries to treat this lightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't I get any say in this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Because I -- ROY (pointing at her) That's what I say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I say is, no. We don't do partners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For Christ's sake, why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mostly, because you scare the shit out of me. I've seen people like you before, baby. Double-tough and sharp as they come, and you get what you want or else. But you don't make it work forever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !! He suddenly gets control of himself, releases her, steps back into the middle of the room. He's angry, but also remorseful, sorry he lost control but still enraged at the enormity of her suggestion.

direction.raw_text: Lilly, almost fainting with relief.

She tosses them onto the bed, checks the case, finds that one of the clasps works but the other doesn't. One is good enough. She carries the attache case out of the room, leaving the light on.

And he's between her and the door.

direction.raw_text: Lilly asleep. Very dim light. The shadows shift on her face as Myra OUT OF FRAME approaches. Myra's hands ENTER FRAME, abruptly clamp on Lilly's throat. Lilly's eyes pop open wide, staring, her mouth stretches open. Myra's arms are locked straight, pressing her weight down onto her hands squeezing Lilly's throat. Lilly clutches at Myra's fingers, tries to reach Myra's face, twists and squirms, then suddenly lifts her arm up and behind her head, hand dipping under the pillow, coming out with the silenced gun, pushing the gun upward, straight-arm, the gun moving up OUT OF FRAME. direction.raw_text: You want a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so. You probably shouldn't either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, but I'm goddamn thirsty. Ice water?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, sure, that sounds nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get it. She stands, putting the attache case on the sofa next to where she was sitting. Roy, with a faint smile, watches her leave the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very small, little used. Dark. Lilly switches on the light when she enters, then leans against the counter, fists clenched and trembling on the counter in front of her. She grits her teeth, hyperventilates, stares around the room in search of escape, an answer, something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly's face, desperate, grim, but not giving up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lilly opens cabinets, finds two glasses, opens the nearly-empty refrigerator, gets ice cubes from a tray, puts them in the glasses, puts the partial tray back in the freezer compartment, fills the glasses from the cold water tap, puts the glasses on the counter, stares at them briefly. She then shakes her head, searches the kitchen some more, and finds a cookie sheet she can use as a tray. She puts the glasses on the tray, carries the tray from the room, leaving the light on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly enters with the tray, crosses to Roy, presents the glasses, speaks as he reaches for one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take whichever one you want. He hesitates. It hadn't occurred to him Lilly might try to poison him or knock him out. He grins at her and takes a glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wouldn't do that. Lilly takes the other glass, puts the cookie sheet on a table, looks down at Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know what I'd do, Roy. You have no idea. To live.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you'll live, Lilly. Lilly crosses back to the sofa, sits beside the attache case, pats it absently as though it is a pet and she's glad it didn't move, waited for her. She sips water, puts the glass on the end table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what's bugging you, of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? I didn't know anything was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, really? You've got a legitimate complaint, Roy, I don't deny that. I wasn't a very good mother when you were a kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not very good! She nods, accepting the correction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bad mother. By any standards. I've thought about it, you know, from your side, since then. I know just how bad I was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder did you ever think about it from my side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I guess not. It was pretty lousy of me, I guess, to be a child at the same time you were. Not to stop being a child just because I had a child. I guess I was a real stinker not to be a grown-up when you needed a grown-up. Roy didn't expect to be made uncomfortable and defensive, and he resents it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to do? Pin a halo on you? You're doing a pretty good job of that yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And making you feel bad at the same time, huh? But that's the way I am, you know, the way I've always been. Always picking on poor little Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For God's sake, Lilly!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave you your life twice. I'm asking you to give me mine once. I need the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Lilly subsides back onto the sofa. One hand rests on the attache case. With the other, she sips water, puts the glass back down. Roy watches her, unmoving, expressionless. Lilly frowns, not quite looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're getting off the grift?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good. You don't really belong on this side of the fence, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you stayed a crook, do you think you'd live to be my ripe age?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see why not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I guess I got it wrong, then. Seems to me I heard about a guy just your age that got hit so hard in the guts it almost killed him. Roy's again unexpectedly uncomfortable. He shifts uneasily in his chair, trying to think of a response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, sure, that doesn't count. That's different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it doesn't matter, does it? I'm getting out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's why you've got to get rid of this money. If you keep it around, it'll just make you think how clever you are. It'll be a temptation to get back into the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, that's it! You're stealing my money for my own good! How very motherly of you, Lilly. Once again, Lilly drops back against the sofa back. Another round in the fight is over. Roy watches her, patient, waiting for her to give up, seeing no other outcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly, frustrated, feeling the need to move, the pressure of pursuit. Her head turns back and forth, her body starts false gestures. Finally, abruptly, she gets to her feet, looks at Roy, looks away, picks up the attache case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy, alert. He won't let her reach the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PANNING with Lilly as she prowls the room, pacing back and forth, the attache case swinging at her side. Finally, she stops, standing the attache case on the coffee table, her hand still on its handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly. She looks at him, attentive without hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I should get out of the racket, that goes double for you. That's why you've got to change your life completely, go to some town, get a square job, live like a john yourself. If you try to do it your way, what future is in it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A future. The only future I've got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That money wouldn't last forever. And then what? You'd be back in some other part of the rackets. Another Bobo Justus to slap you around and burn holes in your hands. This way, you've got to go the square route. You could send me a card when you're settled, I could maybe help out sometimes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what it is, isn't it? Keep me down. Your turn to be in charge, have the power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just trying to help, Lilly. She sits on the sofa again, this time leaving the attache case to stand on the coffee table. She studies Roy, calculating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy... What if I told you I wasn't really your mother? That we weren't related?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Lilly leans back again, but this time her manner is different; languorous, sexy. She crosses her legs, the upper leg swinging gently. She smiles gently, encouragingly, at Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd like that, wouldn't you? Sure you would. You don't need to tell me. Now, why would you like it, Roy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy, understanding and not wanting to understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that all about? Of course you're my mother. Of course you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lilly leans forward toward Roy, inviting him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roy... Roy Roy will not let anything complicated come to the surface.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing more to talk about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to have that money, Roy. What do I have to do to get it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Roy, his face bruised-looking, eyes scared. He will not know what's going on. He shakes his head, not trusting himself to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Lilly, leaning forward, tension showing through the seductive manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No? Won't you give me the money, Roy? Can't I change your mind? What can I do to change your mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , as Lilly gets to her feet and takes a step toward him. Roy's pressed back into his chair, trying to maintain a cold facade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly, Jesus, what are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there nothing I can do, Roy, nothing at -- ROY NO! They both turn away at the same instant. Roy turns to the side to pick up the glass of water, to break the spell and the tension. Lilly turns back toward the coffee table and picks up the attache case. Roy, lifting the glass to drink, turns forward again as Lilly spins forward, swinging the attache case at his head with all her might. The case crashes into the glass and into his face. Roy SCREAMS and topples off the chair, as the one remaining clasp on the case lets go and money goes flying, filling the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DOWN at Roy, face up, expression horrified, hands to his throat. A large triangle of glass is in his throat. Blood pumps thickly, fountaining up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly, staring down in horror. She lurches forward, but there's nothing to do. She stares around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wads of bills on the floor, getting bloody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly, in agony, but looking down, kicking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilly's feet kicking the bills away from the blood. TWO SHOT, as Lilly drops to her knees beside Roy, who's already dying. Blood spurts less forcefully. His hands fall to his sides, eyes stare upward, mouth still moves slightly. Lilly, shoving money away with her hands now, stares at him, willing it not to happen. He stops moving. His eyes dull. Lilly clasps her arms around herself. She knows she doesn't dare scream. Lips drawn back in a snarl, teeth clenched, she
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: her agony through her teeth. She HISSES; she HISSES; she HISSES. Then, slowly, she regains control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Lilly gets to her feet. She seems dazed now, like someone who's just been in a traffic accident. She blunders around the room, kicks the attache case, bends to pick it up. She studies the clasp, sees it still works, goes back to her knees.
direction.name: direction
